column6: Waste diverted from disposal
column13: Since the implementation of this initiative, we have improved the recycled content of some of our products. Cartons can be recycled and re-made into new packaging to help divert waste from landfills. This innovation is better for TWE products, our customers, and the environment.

Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
column7: Two reportable environmental incidents occurred in F23 Ã¢ÂÂ one in Australia and the other in New Zealand. Each incident was minor and led to localised impact with no significant environmental harm. The responsible sites conducted thorough investigations and implemented corrective actions to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.

column6: New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column7: This year, our supplier engagement was expanded to cover our top 100 suppliers globally based on spending. However, only 17 suppliers were able to participate in the survey. This is because many of our suppliers are in the early stages of emissions data collection or have not fully accounted for their scope 1 and 2 emission footprints.

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
Occupation health and safety management system
column13: The health, safety, and wellness of the TWE team and everyone who touches our business remains our highest priority. TWE recognises the importance of ensuring people stay physically and mentally safe by closely managing existing and emerging risks. Our TWE team members recognise that health, safety, and wellness are shared responsibilities, and our people leaders are accountable for managing their people's physical and psychological safety.
column20: Health and Safety Management, Risk Management, Employee Wellness

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: As part of our Build Safe Together campaign, we introduced the concept of a "double-check". It symbolises action that everyone can take to help build safety through Building the habit of stopping to take a moment, thinking, and checking through every task, Calling on others to help us double check we are safe, or offering to check with them, Making it easier to have those stop and check conversations with people around us.
column20: Safety Campaign, Safety Culture, Workplace Communication

column6: Occupational health services
column8: Leader-led change campaign - Build Safe Together
column13: Our vision is to unite everyone by building safe thinking, safe action, and easy conversations into our daily work life across all regions, divisions, roles and people. The program harnesses TWE's team spirit and culture, bringing safety front of mind by developing safe decision-making routines and techniques such as simple language that enables teammates to intervene in the moment were conducted globally, including introducing the Double Check, the Mental Health Double Check, and Every Day Double Checks.
column20: Safety Vision, Safe Decision Making, Recognition Program

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: Launching the TWE Health, Safety & Wellbeing Award to acknowledge the outstanding contribution by an individual employee in establishing and maintaining high standards of health, safety and wellbeing activities and achievements within TWE. Our inaugural winner was Jon Irwin, Barossa Winery Contract Services Coordinator.
column20: Safety Award, Employee Recognition, Health and Safety Excellence

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: Our Barossa Packaging site team member, Cameron Loprete, was awarded the Safety Champion Award by the South Australian Wine Industry Association. This award is given to someone who actively role models workplace health and safety.
column20: Workplace Safety, Role Modeling, Industry Recognition

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column7: We aim to provide education, training and supervision to enable everyone to work safely.
column24: Workplace health safety and wellness policy

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: Initiatives included a range of facilitated sessions across our operating regions with a combination of Mental Health First Aid, Mental Health Awareness sessions for team members, Supporting Mental Health sessions for People Managers and recognition of Mental Health Awareness Month in the US and Men's Health Month in Australia, where guest speakers provided powerful insight into the challenges that experiencing and supporting mental ill health can bring.
column20: Mental Health Awareness, Workplace Wellbeing, Employee Support

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: We refined our mental health and wellbeing action plan to reflect best practices following a review of frameworks and guidelines, including the ISO45003 Standard on managing psychosocial risks.
column20: ISO45003 Standard, Psychosocial Risks Management, Mental Health Action Plan

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column7: Our general approach to health and safety is outlined in the health, safety and wellbeing (HSW) section of this report; however, specific to the management and use of pesticides across our operations, we ensure our employees have the required health and safety practices in place, by the applicable processes and HSE guidelines, whilst handling pesticides and other chemicals.

column6: Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
column7: Our Sonoma Bottling Center achieved 12 consecutive months without a lost time injury (LTI) in the United States. Since most site employees speak Spanish, the team completed 344 Un Momento (take a moment) safety conversations in F23.

column6: Work-related injuries
column7: We have met our F23 target, achieving an SSIFR of 0.2 (our F23 target was an SSIFR of 1.26).

column6: Work-related ill health
Average hours of training per year per employee
Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Our Chief Supply and Sustainability Officer and members of the Supply Leadership Team review and support plans to build engagement and, over the year, have hosted roadshows to host education sessions that demonstrate how IE&D is relevant to all employees and how our ERGs can support employees to feel a greater sense of belonging. In America, IE&D and the ERG topics have been included in Front Line Supervisory training for new and developing front-line leaders. This approach will be applied to Front Line Training in Australia from F24.

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: At TWE, bringing our whole selves to work is in our DNA. Our people's diversity makes us unique, and we strive to create a professional and safe working environment where respect for human rights is the cornerstone of our culture, and everyone can contribute and feel included.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: To extend our leadership capability throughout the business, TWE's development program, Empower Me, originally established for females and non-binary employees to build future leaders, was expanded to include new and emerging leaders from underrepresented groups across the business. This rescoped version of Empower Me is piloted with 30 employees across TWE. As part of the program's objectives, including supporting personal development and growth, these employees have been supported to take leadership roles within TWE Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) and represent TWE publicly.
column20: Leadership Development, Empowerment, Employee Resource Groups

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: To enable our leaders to experience the power of empathy and perspective through storytelling, we led 'Belonging Conversations' with members of the Global Leadership Group (GLG) who are senior leaders within TWE. This experience helped to reinforce and embed our leadership attributes. It was also an opportunity for leaders to practice creating a greater sense of belonging and develop a deeper appreciation of the role of connection in building an inclusive culture.
column20: Belonging Culture, Leadership Attributes, Inclusive Leadership

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column7: To ensure remuneration equity globally, we reviewed our gender pay gap to determine the difference between male and female earnings, irrespective of role or seniority. Five adjustments to remuneration were made due to this analysis in F23.
